I The granting of authority for the operation of all radio stst ons within the boundaries of territories for which the United Kingdom is responsible (including the operation of foreign sponsored stations within those territories) is primarily the responsibility of the local Telecommunication Administration. In the case of the Persian Gulf are; this Administration is vested in the Political Resident, Bahrain v/hc, in consultation with the local Service Authorities (the 'riddle Fast Communica tions Board, Cairo), is responsible for the assignment of frequencies to the radio services to be operated. American sponsored stations in the Persian Gulf area, therefore, equally with British-eperated services, come under the Jurisdic tion of the Political resident and authority for their opera tion should be sought from, and granted by, him. Frequency Allocation . II Frequency allocation should be made in conformity with the provisions of the International Radio Regulations current ly ir. force. In this connection, the Political Resident may find the enclosed copy of the Final Acts of the Atlantic City Corferer.ee, of assistance. It will be seer from article 47 of those Regulations that the Atlantic City frequency alloca tion table (Article 5 of the Regulations) is already in force as far as frequencies above 27.5 k'c/s are concerned whereas for frequencies below 27.5 7c/s the frequency allocation table contained in the International uadio Regulations, Cairo, 1998, (article 7), (a copy of which was enclosed with this Department's letter of the 21st August, 1948, to the Political Resident) will not be superseded by the Atlantic City frequency avoca tion table until a date to be laid down by the special Admini strative Radio Conference which is due to be held In October next. In such cases nevertheless, frequencies should be selected from appro priate bands under the Atlantic ^ity Regulations, according to the type of service to be performed, and should be agreed in consultation with the Middle East Communications Board; and, ^ as a matter of general information, this Department would be glad to be advised of the ultimate allocations. Record of f r equency allocation . VII It is essential that frequencies for new stations in the Persian Gulf area should be allocated so as not to cause interference to existing stations working within the Persian Gulf or elsewhere. It is accordingly recommended that a com prehensive central record of all authorised stations and ser vices in the Persian Gulf area should be kept by the Political Resident. As there is no international call sign block allocated to the Per sian Gulf area, a group of call signs from the United Kingdom international series will be allocated by this Department on receipt of information as to the number of such groups likely 'to be required. titleInfo.title: File No. 17/25 RECORDING OF SHORT WAVE FREQUENCIES BY BAHRAIN AND SHARJAH.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file. Circled serial numbers (red for received correspondence; blue/black for issued correspondence) refer to entries in the notes at the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 32; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-28; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file discusses a letter received from the General Department, Foreign Office relating to the operation of radio stations in the Persian Gulf, including the frequencies that such stations could be operated on and the regulations to be followed in registering frequencies and call signs. Also included is correspondence with political authorities and organisations in the Persian Gulf to compile a central register of all short wave frequencies in use.Further correspondence relates to a request from Petroleum Concessions Limited (Basil Henry Lermitte) for authorisation to install VHF (very high frequency) sets at their offices in Sitra [Sitrah] and Muharraq.A series of file notes which were maintained as a record of the correspondence in the volume can be found at folios 29-30.
